image.altText: For Sale signage outside a suburban house.

items.synopsis: After a brief downturn earlier in the year, Australia's housing market is firmly in recovery mode, with CoreLogic data showing house prices increased for a sixth consecutive month in August.

title.children: House prices rise for sixth straight month, with interest rate outlook likely to see 'active' selling season

image.altText: People on a street hold up signs protesting against the release of wastewater from the Fukushima nuclear plant.

items.synopsis: Japanese businesses and citizens living in China suffer a backlash following the release of treated radioactive wastewater from the damaged Fukushima nuclear power plant.

title.children: Japan started releasing nuclear wastewater into the Pacific last week. The reaction in China has been swift

image.altText: A group of people sitting, each holding and using a mobile phone

items.synopsis: In consideration is having a blanket ban on students using mobile phones from first to last bell, a "put it away" restriction during class time, or a combination of the two depending on a student's year level.

title.children: ACT government calls for community feedback on proposed public school mobile phone ban

image.altText: A woman in pink shirt standing in city street.

items.synopsis: Young culturally diverse Australians continue to face discrimination when trying to find work, according to recent studies. Experts found non-Anglo Australians struggle to get a job interview, despite being well qualified, and some are altering their identities on paper to get a fair go.

title.children: If you're a graduate with an English-sounding name, you may be closer to securing a job than some of your peers

image.altText: Two men with greying hair in suits shake hands on a street watched by other people

items.synopsis: Australia's only Liberal premier is actively campaigning with a Labor prime minister for a Yes vote on a Voice to Parliament, while some of Tasmania's Aboriginal groups are hoping the No vote succeeds.

title.children: Tasmania is the smallest state — but could play a big part as Voice campaign rolls on

image.altText: A person holds a Voice to Parliament official referendum booklet

items.synopsis: The Voice to Parliament campaign is already rife with misinformation. Here are some eyebrow-raising claims you may have seen about the referendum and how you can help ABC Investigations expose more like them.

title.children: Here's some falsehoods you're probably seeing about the Voice and what you can do about it

image.altText: Close up of Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce speaking to the media at a press event.

items.synopsis: Qantas has confirmed it will refund $570 million worth of COVID travel credits for domestic and international customers, while the ACCC has accused the airline of selling tickets for flights it had already cancelled.

title.children: 'People lost faith in the process': Qantas scraps expiry dates on $570m worth of COVID travel credits

image.altText: Australiam Army soldiers stand at attention during an Anzac Day parade

items.synopsis: Hundreds of soldiers could be moved out of South Australia under a planned restructure of the army, with the Department of Defence considering options on how best to transform the service for future "littoral" operations.

title.children: Army considers removing Adelaide-based units

image.altText: A close up street view of an old Japanese house next to an apartment building.

items.synopsis: How does Tokyo's property market compare to Australia's? Here are four unique lessons, from loose zoning laws to smaller dwelling sizes, an advanced public transport system and an openness to development.

title.children: The four unique ways Tokyo approaches housing can offer lessons for Australia

image.altText: A man with tattoos and sunglasses speaks into a microphone; Mitch Mcconnell stares at something offscreen

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Ex-Proud Boys leader gets 17 years over Capitol Riot, doctor says Mitch McConnell 'medically clear'. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Johannesburg apartment block where more than 70 people were killed in a fire overnight is owned by municipal authorities who, more than 12 hours after the blaze broke out, were still unable to provide a clear picture of who had lived there. One official said some rooms may have been rented out by criminal gangs in a so-called "hijacked building". Authorities earlier said more than 50 people were being treated for injuries. "This is a great tragedy felt by families whose loved ones perished in this terrible manner," President Cyril Ramaphosa said in televised remarks. "I do hope that the investigations into the fire will … prevent a repeat of such a tragedy." "It's a wake-up call for us to begin to address the situation of housing in the inner city." Johannesburg officials initially suggested the building had been occupied by squatters. But Lebogang Isaac Maile, the head of the Human Settlements department for Gauteng province, which includes Johannesburg, said some of those who died may have been renting from, or were being extorted by, criminal gangs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Johannesburg fire a 'wake-up call' for city

children.content: A Johannesburg apartment block where more than 70 people were killed in a fire overnight is owned by municipal authorities who, more than 12 hours after the blaze broke out, were still unable to provide a clear picture of who had lived there.

props.alt: A ladder leans against a building blackened with ash

children.content: (Reuters: Shiraaz Mohamed)
One official said some rooms may have been rented out by criminal gangs in a so-called "hijacked building".
Authorities earlier said more than 50 people were being treated for injuries.
"This is a great tragedy felt by families whose loved ones perished in this terrible manner," President Cyril Ramaphosa said in televised remarks.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Voice debate has been mired in misinformation, including unfounded claims around land rights, misleadingly edited videos, and accusations of voter fraud. ABC Investigations wants to know if you think you've seen or received materials containing misinformation. You can let us know here. You can also see some of the claims about the Voice debunked here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tackling misinformation on the Voice

featuredLink.title: Do these claims about the Voice raise an eyebrow?

ABC Investigations

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A federal judge has sentenced former far-right Proud Boys leader Joseph Biggs to 17 years in prison for his role in storming the US Capitol in a failed bid to overturn Donald Trump's 2020 election defeat. Ahead of his sentencing, Biggs apologised for his actions as he faced the judge, choking up as he spoke about his daughter whom he said was a sexual assault victim who needed him. "I was seduced by the crowd, and I just moved forward. My curiosity got the better of me," Biggs said. "I'm not a terrorist. I don't have hate in my heart." There are multiple former Proud Boys being sentenced this morning, so we'll have more updates on that for you shortly.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Seduced by the crowd': Former Proud Boys leader sentenced

children.content: A federal judge has sentenced former far-right Proud Boys leader
Joseph Biggs
to 17 years in prison for his role in storming the US Capitol in a failed bid to overturn
Donald Trump's 2020 election defeat.

props.alt: A man in  a mask takes a selfie inside the US Senate

children.content: Joseph Biggs seen inside the Senate Gallery on January 6, 2021.
(Image: Justice Department)
Ahead of his sentencing, Biggs apologised for his actions as he faced the judge, choking up as he spoke about his daughter whom he said was a sexual assault victim who needed him.
"I was seduced by the crowd, and I just moved forward. My curiosity got the better of me," Biggs said. "I'm not a terrorist. I don't have hate in my heart."
There are multiple former Proud Boys being sentenced this morning, so we'll have more updates on that for you shortly.

items.synopsis: One of the deadliest fires in South Africa leads to more than 74 deaths and scores of injuries, according to emergency services.

title.children: 'Sad day for the city of Johannesburg': More than 70 dead in building blaze

image.altText: Don and Gail, dressed in warm jackets, smile as they stand in front of the sea on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: The town of Korumburra in Victoria's south-east has come together to celebrate the life of Don and Gail Patterson, who police believe died from mushroom poisoning at a family lunch in July.

title.children: 'Lots of love to you all': Suspected mushroom poisoning victim's text to family revealed at memorial service

image.altText: Molina addresses a crowd while wearing a bright pink sari with black and silver beading.

items.synopsis: Getting rid of racism at work isn't just about training courses and diversity posters. Employees should be become more racially literate.

title.children: Molina faced racism at work when she came to Australia. She knows there's a better way

image.altText: Chris Bowen in a navy suit and tie in front of the Australian flag at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Chris Bowen's comments follow warnings from the Australian Energy Market Operator that a hot and dry summer will put Victoria and South Australia at "elevated" risk of blackouts.

image.altText: Aerial photo showing a series of arrays of mirrors arranged in semi-circles facing individual towers

items.synopsis: Renewable energy company RayGen has officially opened its $27 million solar and thermal power plant project, in north-west Victoria.

title.children: These solar energy modules generate enough heat to melt metal. It's hoped they can help solve renewable storage issues

image.altText: A man wearing a suit brings his hands to prayer position in front of his face

items.synopsis: Thaksin, Thailand's most famous politician, returned to his country last week after spending 15 years in self-imposed exile. Upon his arrival he was taken to prison to serve an eight-year sentence for abuse of power and conflicts of interest.

title.children: Thailand's billionaire ex-prime minister requests royal pardon after 15 years in exile

items.synopsis: NSW beekeepers have launched a class action over loss of business after their hives were destroyed to curb the spread of varroa mite.

image.altText: Telstra payphones in Birdsville

image.altText: A woman embraces a soldier as she celebrates in Gabon.

image.altText: Two men in orange shirts, one in a black vest, walk though a motorsport paddock.

image.altText: A composite image showing rock singer Jimmy Barnes, politician Clive Palmer and rapper Eminem.

title.children: 'Moronic charade of a campaign': Ten times musicians told politicians to quit playing their music

title.children: Two men jailed for three years over their role in growing $100m cannabis crop

items.synopsis: Video footage and photographs from the region around Idalia's landfall showed ocean waters washing over highways and neighbourhoods swamped by extensive flooding as residents inspected the damage.

title.children: 'All hell broke loose': Hurricane Idalia tore down houses and flooded neighbourhoods in Florida
